frameDefinitions: A Communicator conveys a Message to an Addressee; the Topic and Medium of the communication also may be expressed.
The words in this frame have to do with non-verbal communication.
In this frame an Informer informs the Authorities of the illegal or otherwise improper Behavior of the Wrongdoer. '
This frame concerns Communicators communicating with each other with the aid of a Means of communication such as a telephone.
This frame describes intentionally formed human social groups (here termed Organizations) with some definite structure and Members.
frameExamples: Let's hope it did n't have time to <t>communicate</t> any of its findings to its overlords.
I <t>gestured</t> with my hand for him to come over.
Tony <t>reported</t> Michael to the police for breaking into his car.
listRoleDefinitions: The sentient entity that uses language in the written or spoken modality to convey a <fen>Message</fen> to the <fen>Addressee</fen>.
<fen>Message</fen> is a proposition or set of propositions that the <fen>Communicator</fen> wants the <fen>Addressee</fen> to believe or take for granted.
The <fen>Topic</fen> is the subject matter to which the <fen>Message</fen> pertains. It is normally expressed as a PP Complement headed by 'about', but in some cases it can appear as a direct object.
The physical or abstract setting in which the <fen>Message</fen> is conveyed.
The time at which the communication takes place.
The location where the act of communication occurs.
This is the sentient entity that communicates a Message non-verbally. It is normally expressed as an External Argument: <fex name='Communicator'>The teacher</fex> <t>gestured</t> us into the room.

This is the person to whom a non-verbal Message is communicated. It may be expressed as an NP Object or as a PP Complement: The teacher <t>gestured</t> <fex name='Addressee'>us</fex> into the room. The teacher <t>gestured</t> <fex name='Addressee'>to us</fex> to enter the room.

This is the content of non-verbal communication. It may be expressed as a <ment>that</ment>-clause Complement, a <ment>to</ment>-marked infinitive VP Complement, or a directional PP Complement: The teacher <t>gestured</t> <fex name='Message'>that it was time to leave</fex>. The teacher <t>gestured</t> to us <fex name='Message'>to enter the room</fex>. The teacher <t>gestured</t> us <fex name='Message'>into the room</fex>.
The <fen>Body_part</fen> is the specific body part of the <fen>Communicator</fen> which gestures.
The <fen>Indicated_entity</fen> is the entity which the <fen>Communicator</fen> is pointing out to the <fen>Addressee</fen> as meaningful.
When the gesturing occus.
The <fen>Place</fen> is where the gesturing occurs.
The <fen>Informer</fen> reports the activities of the <fen>Wrongdoer</fen> to the <fen>Authorities</fen>.
The <fen>Wrongdoer</fen> has his or her activities reported to the <fen>Authorities</fen>.
The <fen>Authorities</fen> are the officials, government or otherwise, who handle misbehavior.
The <fen>Behavior</fen> is the action or actions for which the <fen>Wrongdoer</fen> is reported.
The <fen>Time</fen> when the <fen>Informer</fen> reports the <fen>Behavior</fen> of the <fen>Wrongdoer</fen>.
The <fen>Place</fen> is the location where the reporting occurs.

This role is the person who uses the <fen>Means</fen> of communication to deliver the <fen>Message</fen> to the Addressee. The Speaker is normally expressed as the External Argument of target verbs, or as the Genitive modifier of  nouns.

<fen>Addressee</fen> is the person to whom the <fen>Message</fen> is communicated. When this role is expressed, it often appears in a prepositional phrase introduced by to, or as the direct object, or as the first object in a double object construction.
This role identifies the content that the <fen>Communicator</fen> communicates to the <fen>Addressee</fen>. It can be expressed as a clause or as a noun phrase.
<fen>Topic</fen> is the subject matter to which the <fen>Message</fen> pertains. It is typically expressed as a PP Complement headed by about.

This Frame Element refers to the Instrument of Communication that is used by the <fen>Communicator</fen> (and <fen>Addressee</fen>). Each LU in this frame incorporates the <fen>Means</fen> frame element.
The entity of which the individuals are <fen>Members</fen>.
A person belonging to an <fen>Organization</fen>.
This role describes the general location where the <fen>Organization</fen> operates, but does not indicate the possessor of the <fen>Organization</fen>.
listRoleExamples: <fex>He</fex> finds it hard to communicate with people, not least his separated parents .
How do you communicate to them <fex>that you really like them</fex> ?
Had someone communicated to the capital <fex>about the flagrant disregard of the religious law</fex> ?
Opinions are usually communicated <fex>over the telephone</fex> and are often given within 24 hours.
<fex>The President</fex> cabled his assistant to cancel all of his appointments.
The President cabled <fex>his assistant</fex> to cancel all other engagements.
